transcripts.text: Not to do this to LeBron James or anything, but let's just say he said, I identify as a woman.  Yeah.  And he went to the WNBA.  Yeah.  Destroyed them.  Is that okay?
Yeah, it's okay.

So me as a man, if I started taking a whole bunch of estrogen or some type of hormones to become a woman, and five years later I meet you guys, you would view me as just as much of a woman as you are?  Yes, of course.  Hello everyone, I'm Froland Webster Jr.  with MRCTV and I am out here in Alexandria, Virginia.  I am here to ask people if they think it's okay for biological male athletes who identify as women to compete in women's sports.  Do you all think it is okay for a man who identifies as a woman to enter female sports and play against females as a biological male?
Yes, I think it's fair.  Of course.
I think it's fine.  You can't tell somebody what they feel as a gender.  If they feel like they're a female and they want to compete in female sports, then it should be allowed.
Because if she is a woman, then she's supposed to play... with other women and women's sports.
I don't think it's fair to the women.  Biologically, there are differences with men and women.
Their biological built is masculine.  So I can see where people get upset, but it's not something that you can restrict them on because they want to identify as a woman.

So the U.S.  House of Representatives passed the Equality Act on Friday, which would force federally funded organizations to adhere to someone's gender identity.  So if they want to enter sports, if they want to go into female bathrooms or male bathrooms, it's dependent on the person.  They have to hear that.  It hasn't passed the Senate yet, you know, so it's still a bill.  It's not law.  But is that something you guys would support?
I could support that.
I feel like that's fine.  Again, you can't tell somebody they feel a certain way.  You can't jurisdiction that.
I think it can cause really some drama because now we have to kind of tiptoe around, like, make sure we don't misgender people.

You have these biological males entering the sport.  Yeah.  But the females in the sport, a lot of them don't want them in there because as soon as they come in, they dominate, putting these women at a disadvantage.  And they've been fighting for that, like, their whole lives.  Right.  So is that the right thing?
But, you know, it's just like anything, transgender or not, there always can be somebody that comes in and can dominate the field.
They would feel more comfortable, like, participating among females than with other males, I think.

So my question to that, but there are women who feel uncomfortable with these people coming in.  Transgender athletes would be a huge minority compared to an actual female athlete in this situation.  So should we cater to the minority at the expense of the majority?
Yes, I think so.
We shouldn't be catering to their issue.  I feel like it's more of an emotional thing that needs to be addressed.
Telling them no and you can't do this, that's really heartbreaking.  So I don't know if there should be...

Is that more of an emotional response though?  Emotion as opposed to logic?  Do you play sports?  Yeah, I used to.  What sport?  I did swimming for a while.  So what if Rod here came into your sport, he got some long hair, put it in his sports hat, identifies a woman now, came in, started dominating you.  You finish first all the time.  He comes in, he's first now.  He gets the scholarship he wanted.
That pushes me that much harder to beat him.
He has a physical disadvantage.  I mean, he has a physical advantage over you, and he's faster, he's stronger, and no matter what you do.
I would be upset.  Yeah, I would be upset, 100%.  I can see where these girls are coming from.

I was on the wrestling team in high school.  I was the only girl.  And I hated the meets where I'd have to actually wrestle other guys.  And they're strong.  They're way stronger than me.  I would do the same exercises, whatever, do extra time in the gym, and still get beat up in front of everyone.

Not to do this to LeBron James or anything, but let's just say he said, I identify as a woman.  And he went to the WNBA, destroyed them.  Championship after championship after championship.  Is that OK?
Yeah, it's okay.
That's okay.
For me, it's okay.
Just the women need to work harder then.  Women need to work harder to compete with LeBron James.
I think that they 100% can.  I think that they can.
To beat LeBron James?  Yeah, I think so.  Why not?  Okay, okay.  And be honest.
I mean, I think that would be unfair because his height and his weight and his, you know, strength.
You said his.  So he would.  Oh, her.
Right.  Her height, weight and strength compared to naturally born woman will be way off the charts compared to them.
But don't that sound weird to you.  to just change it up to her?  You know LeBron James is a dude.
Yeah, but it takes getting used to.
I think that mentally they were always whatever gender they identified as, but now physically they are also that gender.
Would that same thing apply if the person thought they were like a dog or a reptile?
Well, no, because...
Why?  What's the difference?
Well, you can't...

Uh-oh.  You can't get like... You haven't seen people who have gone through surgeries that look more like a reptile?  No.  Get their tongue split and they get all the tattoos and stuff.  So I mean, they're a reptile, right?  So you got one trans athlete, you got a hundred female athletes.  You should cater to that one trans athlete?  Allow the man or the woman to say no?
No, the trans athlete should adjust to the sport how it is.
Yeah, but the sport how it is is women only.
Well, I mean, if they identify as a woman, then they should be allowed to join.
So a man who identifies as a woman is as much of a woman as you are?
I think so.
Really?  What do you say to people who say, you're wrong.  Biological males who identify as women should be able to play against women because they are women.  What do you say to them?

I would say, think about it a little bit more.  Think about the biological aspect.  Ignore the emotions.  It's going to be hard for that gender confused person in a lot of aspects of their life, not just competitive sports.  If they want to do competitive sports, then maybe they shouldn't take estrogen and maybe they should embrace their testosterone and win against the guys.
